title: Cat. 98  Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Wall Revetment  
Late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 4.4 × 4.4 × 0.3 cm (1 3/4 × 1 3/4 × 1/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1275

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent robin’s-egg-blue, translucent brown, and opaque white and greenish-yellow glass. Wall revetment fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished on the face. The fragment preserves the left and right sides of an inlay; two adjacent sides are broken. In a brown matrix is a mosaic pattern formed from segments of two canes: one of small rods of greenish yellow that vary in section from ovoid to square to triangular; the second a stylized rosette of robin’s-egg blue with a center surrounded by seven petals, all outlined in white.

The face has been repolished; the edges and back are heavily pitted with a dully iridescent weathering crust.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 98 Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.

</section>
